name: Spicy Black-Eyed Pea Curry with Swiss Chard and Roasted Eggplant
instructions: Rinse the black-eyed peas and soak in several inches of water for 6 hours or overnight. Drain and rinse, then transfer to a large saucepan and cover with fresh water. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer for 40 to 60 minutes. Take care not to overcook  the beans should be tender but not be falling apart. Drain and set aside.To prepare the eggplant, cut of the stem and bottom edge and then cut in half lengthwise. Score the flesh into diagonal 1-inch lines, then turn and score again until you have a diagonal pattern. Take care not to cut through the skin. Sprinkle with some salt and let sit for 40 minutes. Rinse and squeeze out any excess water. Brush the eggplant with some oil and transfer to a roasting pan. Bake in a preheated 400 oven until the flesh appears collapsed and is wrinkly. Remove from heat and let cool for about 10 minutes, season with a bit of salt, and remove the flesh from the eggplant. If there is too much water, drain in a strainer. Set aside.Heat the oil over medium heat in the same saucepan used to cook the black-eyed peas. When hot, toss in the shallots and chilies and saut for 2 to 3 minutes. Now add the spices and stir for another minute, until fragrant. Add the tomato, cook for another few minutes, and then add the eggplant and black-eyed peas, and cook for another few minutes, stirring often.Pour a few tablespoons of water into the pan and add handfuls of chard at a time until wilted. Add more water as necessary. Add the lemon juice and salt to taste near the end of the cooking time. Remove from heat, cover, and let sit for a few minutes before serving.

processGraph.recipeName: Spicy Black-Eyed Pea Curry with Swiss Chard and Roasted Eggplant

processSteps.originalInstruction: Rinse the black-eyed peas and soak in several inches of water for 6 hours or overnight.

processes.notes: soak in water for 6 hours or overnight

processSteps.outputDescription: clean, hydrated black-eyed peas ready for cooking

processSteps.originalInstruction: Drain and rinse, then transfer to a large saucepan and cover with fresh water.
processSteps.outputDescription: drained and rinsed peas in saucepan with fresh water

processSteps.originalInstruction: Bring to a boil, reduce heat to medium-low, cover, and simmer for 40 to 60 minutes.
processSteps.outputDescription: tender cooked black-eyed peas, not falling apart

processSteps.originalInstruction: Take care not to overcook the beans should be tender but not be falling apart. Drain and set aside.
processSteps.outputDescription: cooked, drained black-eyed peas set aside

processSteps.originalInstruction: To prepare the eggplant, cut of the stem and bottom edge and then cut in half lengthwise.
processSteps.outputDescription: eggplant halved lengthwise with ends trimmed

processSteps.originalInstruction: Score the flesh into diagonal 1-inch lines, then turn and score again until you have a diagonal pattern. Take care not to cut through the skin.

processes.notes: diagonal crosshatch pattern, 1-inch lines, don't cut through skin

processSteps.outputDescription: eggplant halves with diagonal crosshatch scoring pattern

processSteps.originalInstruction: Sprinkle with some salt and let sit for 40 minutes.

processes.notes: let sit to draw out moisture

processSteps.outputDescription: salted eggplant that has released excess moisture

processSteps.originalInstruction: Rinse and squeeze out any excess water.
processSteps.outputDescription: rinsed eggplant with excess moisture removed

processSteps.originalInstruction: Brush the eggplant with some oil and transfer to a roasting pan.
Bake in a preheated 400 oven until the flesh appears collapsed and is wrinkly.

processes.notes: 400°F oven until flesh collapses and wrinkles

processSteps.outputDescription: roasted eggplant with collapsed, wrinkled flesh

processSteps.originalInstruction: Remove from heat and let cool for about 10 minutes, season with a bit of salt, and remove the flesh from the eggplant.
processSteps.outputDescription: cooled, seasoned eggplant flesh removed from skin

processSteps.originalInstruction: If there is too much water, drain in a strainer. Set aside.
Heat the oil over medium heat in the same saucepan used to cook the black-eyed peas.
When hot, toss in the shallots and chilies and sauté for 2 to 3 minutes.
Now add the spices and stir for another minute, until fragrant.
processSteps.outputDescription: fragrant spice mixture combined with aromatics

processSteps.originalInstruction: Add the tomato, cook for another few minutes, and then add the eggplant and black-eyed peas, and cook for another few minutes, stirring often.

processes.notes: add eggplant and peas, stir often

processSteps.outputDescription: combined curry base with eggplant and black-eyed peas

processSteps.originalInstruction: Pour a few tablespoons of water into the pan and add handfuls of chard at a time until wilted.
processSteps.outputDescription: wilted swiss chard incorporated into curry

processSteps.originalInstruction: Add more water as necessary. Add the lemon juice and salt to taste near the end of the cooking time.

processes.notes: add lemon juice and salt to taste

processSteps.outputDescription: seasoned curry with bright lemon flavor

processSteps.originalInstruction: Remove from heat, cover, and let sit for a few minutes before serving.
